summary: The past couple of lessons have all focused on different types of transport across the cell membrane. This is an essential process of all cells and necessary for their functions, as well as for life as a whole. Topic 2.8 serves as a review of passive transport, active transport, and osmosis.

vocab.definition: Occurs when there is a difference in concentration of a substance between two regions, and the substance will move from areas of high concentration to low until equilibrium is reached
The movement of molecules across a membrane from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration, without the cell expending its own energy
The cellular process of moving molecules across a cell membrane against their concentration gradient, requiring cellular energy, typically in the form of ATP, to drive the process
Integral membrane proteins that form pores in the membrane, allowing specific molecules or ions to pass through by diffusion
Integral membrane proteins that form pores in the membrane, allowing specific molecules or ions to pass through by diffusion
A protein in the cell membrane that performs active transport, pumping three sodium (Na+) ions out of the cell for every two potassium (K+) ions that are pumped in
The combined force driving ions across a cell membrane, resulting from both a chemical gradient (difference in concentration) and an electrical gradient (difference in electrical charge)
